elements.content:
Three independent 1D metal–organic nanotubes AgL 2X2 [X = PF6 – (1), ClO4 – (2), and SbF6 – (3)] with anion exchange, separation, and anion-responsive photoluminescence are reported.

Three independent 1D metal−organic nanotubes AgL 2X2 (X = PF6 −, ClO4 −, and SbF6 −) with anion exchange, separation, and anion-responsive photoluminescence are reported.

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted significant attention because of their potential applications in gas storage, chemical separation, catalysis, and luminescence. Despite numerous MOFs with tubular channels described in the literature, however, reports of the independent 1D nanosized metal–organic tubes are quite rare to date. As we know, the construction of discrete 1D metal–organic nanotubes is very hard because of the inherent difficulty in the design and synthesis of the organic ligands with specific binding sites and orientations required by the tubular structures. On the other hand, a versatile metal coordination geometry is not easy to meet with the linking mode of the organic ligand to form a discrete 1D cylindrical structure.
elements.clean_text:
Three independent 1D metal-organic nanotubes AgL 2X2 [X = PF6 - (1), ClO4 - (2), and SbF6 - (3)] with anion exchange, separation, and anion-responsive photoluminescence are reported.

Three independent 1D metal-organic nanotubes AgL 2X2 (X = PF6 -, ClO4 -, and SbF6 -) with anion exchange, separation, and anion-responsive photoluminescence are reported.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted significant attention because of their potential applications in gas storage, chemical separation, catalysis, and luminescence. Despite numerous MOFs with tubular channels described in the literature, however, reports of the independent 1D nanosized metal-organic tubes are quite rare to date. As we know, the construction of discrete 1D metal-organic nanotubes is very hard because of the inherent difficulty in the design and synthesis of the organic ligands with specific binding sites and orientations required by the tubular structures. On the other hand, a versatile metal coordination geometry is not easy to meet with the linking mode of the organic ligand to form a discrete 1D cylindrical structure.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Synthesis of <bold>L</bold>
</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr7" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic-2011-01765u_0008.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

One of the promising approaches for the construction of independent 1D metal–organic nanotubes is to make use of metal–organic nanospirals. As we know, helical chains can form hollow, tube-shaped structures during their extension. The appropriate choice of organic spacers with specific geometry is a major factor in achieving helical chains and, furthermore, tubular structures. As shown in Scheme , the multifunctional double-Schiff-base ligand L was deliberately designed. It possesses a central chelating N,N site, which can bind to a metal ion to force itself into a cis conformation with a bent shape. In addition, the flexible −CH2CH2– linker would induce two long phenylpyridine arms to be noncoplanar but twist. Such a scaffold is inclined to link metal nodes to form a helical array rather than a spherical one (Scheme ).
elements.clean_text: One of the promising approaches for the construction of independent 1D metal-organic nanotubes is to make use of metal-organic nanospirals. As we know, helical chains can form hollow, tube-shaped structures during their extension. The appropriate choice of organic spacers with specific geometry is a major factor in achieving helical chains and, furthermore, tubular structures. As shown in Scheme , the multifunctional double-Schiff-base ligand L was deliberately designed. It possesses a central chelating N,N site, which can bind to a metal ion to force itself into a cis conformation with a bent shape. In addition, the flexible -CH2CH2- linker would induce two long phenylpyridine arms to be noncoplanar but twist. Such a scaffold is inclined to link metal nodes to form a helical array rather than a spherical one (Scheme ).

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch2" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>2</label>
<caption>
<title>Formation of a Helical Chain Based on a
Metal-Ion-Assisted Bent Organic
Ligand</title>

<graphic id="gr8" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic-2011-01765u_0009.tif"></graphic>

elements.clean_text: 2  Formation of a Helical Chain Based on a Metal-Ion-Assisted Bent Organic Ligand

elements.content: Depending on this approach, a series of independent 1D nanosized metal–organic tubes Ag2 L 2X2 [X = PF6 – (1), ClO4 – (2) and SbF6 – (3)] are synthesized. X-ray crystal structure analysis () revealed that 1–3 are isostructural and crystallize in the orthorhombic space group Ccca. For example, in 1, there are two crystallographically independent AgI centers, and they all lie in a distorted tetrahedral coordination sphere (). As shown in Figure , AgI ions are linked together by AgI-assisted bent ligand L into a 1D helical chain with a period of separation of ∼32 Å.
elements.clean_text: Depending on this approach, a series of independent 1D nanosized metal-organic tubes Ag2 L 2X2 [X = PF6 - (1), ClO4 - (2) and SbF6 - (3)] are synthesized. X-ray crystal structure analysis () revealed that 1-3 are isostructural and crystallize in the orthorhombic space group Ccca. For example, in 1, there are two crystallographically independent AgI centers, and they all lie in a distorted tetrahedral coordination sphere (). As shown in Figure , AgI ions are linked together by AgI-assisted bent ligand L into a 1D helical chain with a period of separation of ~32 Å.

elements.content: Side (left) and top (right) views of a 1D single-helical chain in 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  Side (left) and top (right) views of a 1D single-helical chain in 1.

elements.content: Notably, each four-coordinate AgI ion serves as not only a node to bend the Schiff-base ligand but also a connector to extend the helical chain along the crystallographic c axis. Upon close inspection of the structure, there are two sets of helical strands in 1. Figure shows that each strand consists of two individual one-handed helical chains that symmetrically surround the central axis to form an ellipselike tubular structure. Furthermore, two sets of strands intertwine each other and are interlocked by a {AgN2} linkage to eventually form a squarelike nanotube. The open channel of ∼1.1 × 1.1 nm dimensions is filled with PF6 – counterions and disordered MeOH molecules.
elements.clean_text: Notably, each four-coordinate AgI ion serves as not only a node to bend the Schiff-base ligand but also a connector to extend the helical chain along the crystallographic c axis. Upon close inspection of the structure, there are two sets of helical strands in 1. Figure  shows that each strand consists of two individual one-handed helical chains that symmetrically surround the central axis to form an ellipselike tubular structure. Furthermore, two sets of strands intertwine each other and are interlocked by a {AgN2} linkage to eventually form a squarelike nanotube. The open channel of ~1.1 × 1.1 nm dimensions is filled with PF6 - counterions and disordered MeOH molecules.

elements.content: Left- and right-handed strands consisting of a nanotube.
elements.clean_text: 2  Left- and right-handed strands consisting of a nanotube.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , the P2F6 – anion is weakly bound to the framework through two sets of C–H···F bonds. The hydrogen-bonding system involves the F atom of PF6 – and the pyridyl H atom on the framework. The F6···C5 and F7···C4 distances are 3.257(5) and 3.294(5) Å, respectively. The corresponding F···H–C angles are 141 and 125°, respectively. In addition, the packing of adjacent tubes along the crystallographic c axis also leads to smaller open square channels of ∼6.6 × 6.6 Å that are occupied by the rest of the P1F6 – anions (Figure ). This is different from P2F6 – in the tube; P1F6 – is tightly bound by multiple F···H–C bonds (). Notably, the encapsulated MeOH guests can escape from the channel cavities at room temperature to generate the solvent-free Ag2 L 2 tube, which was confirmed by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; Figure ). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns indicate that the framework of 1 remains intact upon removal of all MeOH molecules ().
elements.clean_text: As shown in Figure , the P2F6 - anion is weakly bound to the framework through two sets of C-H⋅⋅⋅F bonds. The hydrogen-bonding system involves the F atom of PF6 - and the pyridyl H atom on the framework. The F6⋅⋅⋅C5 and F7⋅⋅⋅C4 distances are 3.257(5) and 3.294(5) Å, respectively. The corresponding F⋅⋅⋅H-C angles are 141 and 125°, respectively. In addition, the packing of adjacent tubes along the crystallographic c axis also leads to smaller open square channels of ~6.6 × 6.6 Å that are occupied by the rest of the P1F6 - anions (Figure ). This is different from P2F6 - in the tube; P1F6 - is tightly bound by multiple F⋅⋅⋅H-C bonds (). Notably, the encapsulated MeOH guests can escape from the channel cavities at room temperature to generate the solvent-free Ag2 L 2 tube, which was confirmed by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; Figure ). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns indicate that the framework of 1 remains intact upon removal of all MeOH molecules ().

elements.content: Encapsulated PF6 – anion fixed by two sets of F···H hydrogen bonds in 1. The encapsulated MeOH molecules have been removed for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  Encapsulated PF6 - anion fixed by two sets of F⋅⋅⋅H hydrogen bonds in 1. The encapsulated MeOH molecules have been removed for clarity.

elements.content: Left: Crystal packing of 1. Right: TGA trace on a desolvated sample of 1.
elements.clean_text: 4  Left: Crystal packing of 1. Right: TGA trace on a desolvated sample of 1.

elements.content: Anion recognition and separation is currently a very active topic because various anions play central role in chemical and biological processes. The design of anion receptors, however, is challenging. As shown above, compounds 1–3 are cationic metal–organic tubes, and the counterions occupied the framework void and were uncoordinated to the metal centers. So, we wondered if the encapsulated anions could be exchanged by other kinds of anions. When the crystals of 1 were stirred in a tetrahydrofuran (THF)/methanol (MeOH) (1:1, v/v) solution of NaClO4 (excess), the IR spectra indicated that the typical bands associated with ClO4 – (∼1090 cm–1) appeared. As time went on, the intensity of the ClO4 – band increased, while the intensity of the PF6 – band (∼840 cm–1) decreased. After 8 h, no more changes for the band intensity have been observed, indicating that the exchange reaction of PF6 – by ClO4 – finished (Figure ). The PXRD patterns suggest that the skeletal structure of the tube remains intact after anion exchange (). Ion chromatography measurement indicated that 63.26% of the PF6 – anions in 1 were exchanged by ClO4 – to result in a mixed-anion compound (4).
elements.clean_text: Anion recognition and separation is currently a very active topic because various anions play central role in chemical and biological processes. The design of anion receptors, however, is challenging. As shown above, compounds 1-3 are cationic metal-organic tubes, and the counterions occupied the framework void and were uncoordinated to the metal centers. So, we wondered if the encapsulated anions could be exchanged by other kinds of anions. When the crystals of 1 were stirred in a tetrahydrofuran (THF)/methanol (MeOH) (1:1, v/v) solution of NaClO4 (excess), the IR spectra indicated that the typical bands associated with ClO4 - (~1090 cm-1) appeared. As time went on, the intensity of the ClO4 - band increased, while the intensity of the PF6 - band (~840 cm-1) decreased. After 8 h, no more changes for the band intensity have been observed, indicating that the exchange reaction of PF6 - by ClO4 - finished (Figure ). The PXRD patterns suggest that the skeletal structure of the tube remains intact after anion exchange (). Ion chromatography measurement indicated that 63.26% of the PF6 - anions in 1 were exchanged by ClO4 - to result in a mixed-anion compound (4).

elements.content: Left: IR spectra of 1 and its anion-exchanged products (PF6 – by ClO4 –) obtained after 1 h (1a), 4 h (1b), and 8 h (1c). Right: IR spectra of 1 and its anion-exchanged products (PF6 – by SbF6 –) obtained after 1 h (1d), 4 h (1e), and 8 h (1f).
elements.clean_text: 5  Left: IR spectra of 1 and its anion-exchanged products (PF6 - by ClO4 -) obtained after 1 h (1a), 4 h (1b), and 8 h (1c). Right: IR spectra of 1 and its anion-exchanged products (PF6 - by SbF6 -) obtained after 1 h (1d), 4 h (1e), and 8 h (1f).

elements.content: Besides ClO4 –, PF6 – in 1 can also be replaced by SbF6 –. The crystals of 1 were suspended in a THF/MeOH (1:1, v/v) solution of NH4SbF6 and stirred for 8 h; the anion-exchanged product was obtained. The anion-exchange process was monitored by the enhanced intensity at 658 cm–1 of the SbF6 – band, as well as the reduced intensity at 840 cm–1 of the PF6 – band (Figure ). Again, the ion chromatography analysis suggested that 61.43% of the PF6 – anions were replaced by SbF6 – to generate a mixed-anion compound (5), and the PXRD patterns confirmed the framework to be intact upon anion exchange (). It is worth noting that anion exchange of 1–3 was found to be highly selective; only the substitution of PF6 – in 1 by ClO4 – or SbF6 – was achieved, whereas ClO4 – in 2 and SbF6 – in 3 could not be replaced by PF6 – or SbF6 – and ClO4 – or PF6 –, respectively, which is further confirmed by the fact that 1 cannot be regenerated upon the addition of PF6 – to 4 and 5 under the experimental conditions. Additionally, trigonal-planar NO3 – was also used to exchange the octahedral PF6 – in 1, SbF6 – in 2, and the tetrahedral ClO4 – in 3 under the same experimental conditions, but they did not work. This demonstrates that this anion-exchange process depends on the size and geometry of the anion in relation to the size of the void in the host tube.
elements.clean_text: Besides ClO4 -, PF6 - in 1 can also be replaced by SbF6 -. The crystals of 1 were suspended in a THF/MeOH (1:1, v/v) solution of NH4SbF6 and stirred for 8 h; the anion-exchanged product was obtained. The anion-exchange process was monitored by the enhanced intensity at 658 cm-1 of the SbF6 - band, as well as the reduced intensity at 840 cm-1 of the PF6 - band (Figure ). Again, the ion chromatography analysis suggested that 61.43% of the PF6 - anions were replaced by SbF6 - to generate a mixed-anion compound (5), and the PXRD patterns confirmed the framework to be intact upon anion exchange (). It is worth noting that anion exchange of 1-3 was found to be highly selective; only the substitution of PF6 - in 1 by ClO4 - or SbF6 - was achieved, whereas ClO4 - in 2 and SbF6 - in 3 could not be replaced by PF6 - or SbF6 - and ClO4 - or PF6 -, respectively, which is further confirmed by the fact that 1 cannot be regenerated upon the addition of PF6 - to 4 and 5 under the experimental conditions. Additionally, trigonal-planar NO3 - was also used to exchange the octahedral PF6 - in 1, SbF6 - in 2, and the tetrahedral ClO4 - in 3 under the same experimental conditions, but they did not work. This demonstrates that this anion-exchange process depends on the size and geometry of the anion in relation to the size of the void in the host tube.

elements.content: The major hurdle in anionic separation is selectivity, that is, the preparation of a host framework that responds to only one kind of specific anion species in the presence of other different potential competitors. As mentioned above, PF6 – in the tube of 1 can be replaced by both ClO4 – and SbF6 –, so we wondered if 1 could be used as a selective anionic acceptor to separate ClO4 – and SbF6 –. When the crystals of 1 were stirred in a THF/MeOH (1:1, v/v) solution of equimolar NH4SbF6 and NaClO4 for 6 h, only the characteristic bands of PF6 – (∼840 cm–1) and ClO4 – (1090 cm–1) were found in the IR spectra; the characteristic band (∼658 cm–1) of SbF6 –, however, was not observed (). The result demonstrates that only ClO4 – was allowed into the channel to exchange PF6 –. Therefore, between ClO4 – and SbF6 –, ClO4 – is the preferred anionic species for the host tube of 1. The PXRD patterns indicate that the structure of 1 is stable during the anion-exchange process ().
elements.clean_text: The major hurdle in anionic separation is selectivity, that is, the preparation of a host framework that responds to only one kind of specific anion species in the presence of other different potential competitors. As mentioned above, PF6 - in the tube of 1 can be replaced by both ClO4 - and SbF6 -, so we wondered if 1 could be used as a selective anionic acceptor to separate ClO4 - and SbF6 -. When the crystals of 1 were stirred in a THF/MeOH (1:1, v/v) solution of equimolar NH4SbF6 and NaClO4 for 6 h, only the characteristic bands of PF6 - (~840 cm-1) and ClO4 - (1090 cm-1) were found in the IR spectra; the characteristic band (~658 cm-1) of SbF6 -, however, was not observed (). The result demonstrates that only ClO4 - was allowed into the channel to exchange PF6 -. Therefore, between ClO4 - and SbF6 -, ClO4 - is the preferred anionic species for the host tube of 1. The PXRD patterns indicate that the structure of 1 is stable during the anion-exchange process ().

elements.content: We have been exploring the guest-driven luminescent property based on porous MOFs. As a part of our systematic study on this subject, a luminescent emission spectrum was used to monitor the anion-exchange process. Interestingly, these anions⊂Ag2 L 2 systems show an interesting anion-responsive photoluminescence. As shown in Figure , 1 exhibits intense green emission at 527 nm upon excitation at 448 nm, which is of great interest because of an emission characteristic similar to that of a green fluorescent protein of Topaz (T203Y type). In comparison with the emission of free L (528 nm upon excitation at 448 nm; ), the emission of 1 should be assigned to the ligand-centered (n-π* or π–π*) emission because almost identical emission bands are observed. Compared to 1, 2 and 3 show distinctly different emission properties. The ligand-centered emission intensity in 2 or 3 is dramatically quenched (Figure ), which is clearly attributed to the different anion inclusions. As expected, the emission intensity of 1 decreased by degrees as the incorporated PF6 – was gradually replaced by ClO4 – in 2 and SbF6 – in 3, respectively. So, such a metal–organic tube also acts as a luminescent receptor for selective anion monitoring, which might be of biological, environmental, and industrial interest.
elements.clean_text: We have been exploring the guest-driven luminescent property based on porous MOFs. As a part of our systematic study on this subject, a luminescent emission spectrum was used to monitor the anion-exchange process. Interestingly, these anions⊂Ag2 L 2 systems show an interesting anion-responsive photoluminescence. As shown in Figure , 1 exhibits intense green emission at 527 nm upon excitation at 448 nm, which is of great interest because of an emission characteristic similar to that of a green fluorescent protein of Topaz (T203Y type). In comparison with the emission of free L (528 nm upon excitation at 448 nm; ), the emission of 1 should be assigned to the ligand-centered (n-π* or π-π*) emission because almost identical emission bands are observed. Compared to 1, 2 and 3 show distinctly different emission properties. The ligand-centered emission intensity in 2 or 3 is dramatically quenched (Figure ), which is clearly attributed to the different anion inclusions. As expected, the emission intensity of 1 decreased by degrees as the incorporated PF6 - was gradually replaced by ClO4 - in 2 and SbF6 - in 3, respectively. So, such a metal-organic tube also acts as a luminescent receptor for selective anion monitoring, which might be of biological, environmental, and industrial interest.

elements.content: Left: Emission spectra of 1 and 2 and anion-exchanged products based on 1 (PF6 – by ClO4 –) at 1 h (1a), 4 h (1b), and 8 h (1c). Right: Emission spectra of 1 and 3 and anion-exchanged products based on 1 (PF6 – by SbF6 –) at 1 h (1d), 4 h (1e), and 8 h (1f).
elements.clean_text: 6  Left: Emission spectra of 1 and 2 and anion-exchanged products based on 1 (PF6 - by ClO4 -) at 1 h (1a), 4 h (1b), and 8 h (1c). Right: Emission spectra of 1 and 3 and anion-exchanged products based on 1 (PF6 - by SbF6 -) at 1 h (1d), 4 h (1e), and 8 h (1f).

elements.content:
We expect this approach to be viable for the construction of many more new tubular MOFs, and studies toward the preparation of new discrete nanotubes in our laboratory are underway.

X-ray crystallographic data in CIF format, syntheses of L and 1–3, TGA and PXRD, spectra, and single-crystal data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References

Some typical discrete metal–organic tubes:

As a part of our systematic study on this subject, a luminescent emission spectrum was used to monitor the anion-exchange process. Interestingly, these anions⊂Ag2 L 2 systems show an interesting anion-responsive photoluminescence. As shown in Figure , 1 exhibits intense green emission at 527 nm upon excitation at 448 nm, which is of great interest because of an emission characteristic similar to that of a green fluorescent protein of Topaz (T203Y type). In comparison with the emission of free L (528 nm upon excitation at 448 nm; ), the emission of 1 should be assigned to the ligand-centered (n-π* or π–π*) emission because almost identical emission bands are observed. Compared to 1, 2 and 3 show distinctly different emission properties. The ligand-centered emission intensity in 2 or 3 is dramatically quenched (Figure ), which is clearly attributed to the different anion inclusions. As expected, the emission intensity of 1 decreased by degrees as the incorporated PF6 – was gradually replaced by ClO4 – in 2 and SbF6 – in 3, respectively. So, such a metal–organic tube also acts as a luminescent receptor for selective anion monitoring, which might be of biological, environmental, and industrial interest.

metadata.title:
Independent 1D Nanosized
Metal–Organic Tube:
Anion Exchange, Separation, and Anion-Responsive Luminescence
